elements.content: We report the synthesis and structural characterization of a unique Co-MOF-1 with the formula [Co2(dpmndi)­(bdc)2)]·DMF; (dpmndi = N,N′-bis­(4-pyridylmethyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalenediimide and bdc = benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate) along with an isonicotinate based Co-MOF-2 having the formula of [Co3(ina)4(OH)­(H2O)3]·H2O·NO3. A single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that Co-MOFs 1 and 2 exhibits (5)-connected and (8)-connected three-dimensional framework architecture having tts and hex topology, respectively. Importantly, Co-MOF-1 possess microsized cage with an internal cavity of 8.6 Å. The gas sorption analysis was also performed on both Co-MOFs 1 and 2, and results show high uptake for N2 and CO2 compared to H2 and CH4. Moreover, both Co-MOFs 1 and 2 display high value of isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) for CO2 gas. In addition, Co-MOF-1 also exhibits the promising solvatochromic behavior.

A single crystal X-ray analysis reveals that Co-MOFs 1 and 2 exhibits (5)-connected and (8)-connected three-dimensional framework architecture having tts and hex topology, respectively. Importantly, Co-MOF-1 possess microsized cage with an internal cavity of 8.6 Å. The gas sorption analysis was also performed on both Co-MOFs 1 and 2, and results show high uptake for N2 and CO2 compared to H2 and CH4. Moreover, both Co-MOFs 1 and 2 display high value of isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) for CO2 gas. In addition, Co-MOF-1 also exhibits the promising solvatochromic behavior.

elements.content: Co-MOF-1 based on N,N′-bis­(4-pyridylmethyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalenediimide (dpmndi) and benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate (bdc) and an isonicotinate based Co-MOF-2 were reported. The Co-MOFs 1 and 2 exhibit (5)-connected and (8)-connected 3D framework architecture with tts and hex topology, respectively. The gas sorption analysis for Co-MOFs 1 and 2 shows high uptake capacities and isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) for CO2 gas. Notably, Co-MOF-1 also shows promising solvatochromic behavior.

The Co-MOFs 1 and 2 exhibit (5)-connected and (8)-connected 3D framework architecture with tts and hex topology, respectively. The gas sorption analysis for Co-MOFs 1 and 2 shows high uptake capacities and isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) for CO2 gas. Notably, Co-MOF-1 also shows promising solvatochromic behavior.

elements.content: Over the past few years the design and development of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted tremendous attention of the wider scientific community, not only because of their molecular connectivity and topologies but also due to their wide range of societally and industrially relevant potential applications such as heterogeneous catalysis, drug delivery, molecular recognition, sensing, optics, luminescence, ion exchange, ionic/electronic conductivity, magnetism, and gas sorption. In addition, similar to naturally occurring zeolites, MOFs also contain large cavities in their structures; however, the versatility and adaptively in the coordination mode of the linkers together with the geometrical preference of the constitutive metal ions provide an advantage to tune the porosity and topology of the resultant architecture and thus provide advantage over the zeolites and mesoporous silica. The MOFs can be synthesized by using an organic linker and a suitable metal ion. However, there are several reaction factors such as temperature, pH, metal-to-ligand ratios, solvent systems, and so on that influence the topology of the resultant architecture. Therefore, the synthesis of multifunctional MOFs with the desired structural topology and applications is still a challenging task for the researcher. To date, tremendous efforts and strategies have been used by the researchers to construct the multifunctional MOFs for diverse range of applications. The mixed-ligand strategy is one of them and widely examined in recent years as this is the very straightforward procedure and also retains the structural integrity of the resultant structure. In this approach, different linkers with different donor atoms are mixed before synthesis. Though, this protocol is well explored, yet, only few literature examples are available wherein the naphthalenediimide (NDI) based linker along with the coligand have been used for the solvothermal preparation of a three-dimensional multifunctional MOF.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past few years the design and development of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted tremendous attention of the wider scientific community, not only because of their molecular connectivity and topologies but also due to their wide range of societally and industrially relevant potential applications such as heterogeneous catalysis, drug delivery, molecular recognition, sensing, optics, luminescence, ion exchange, ionic/electronic conductivity, magnetism, and gas sorption. In addition, similar to naturally occurring zeolites, MOFs also contain large cavities in their structures; however, the versatility and adaptively in the coordination mode of the linkers together with the geometrical preference of the constitutive metal ions provide an advantage to tune the porosity and topology of the resultant architecture and thus provide advantage over the zeolites and mesoporous silica. The MOFs can be synthesized by using an organic linker and a suitable metal ion. However, there are several reaction factors such as temperature, pH, metal-to-ligand ratios, solvent systems, and so on that influence the topology of the resultant architecture. Therefore, the synthesis of multifunctional MOFs with the desired structural topology and applications is still a challenging task for the researcher. To date, tremendous efforts and strategies have been used by the researchers to construct the multifunctional MOFs for diverse range of applications. The mixed-ligand strategy is one of them and widely examined in recent years as this is the very straightforward procedure and also retains the structural integrity of the resultant structure. In this approach, different linkers with different donor atoms are mixed before synthesis. Though, this protocol is well explored, yet, only few literature examples are available wherein the naphthalenediimide (NDI) based linker along with the coligand have been used for the solvothermal preparation of a three-dimensional multifunctional MOF.

elements.content: Herein, we report the design and synthesis of a unique Co-MOF-1 with the formula [Co2(dpmndi)­(bdc)2]·DMF; (dpmndi = N,N′-bis­(4-pyridylmethyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalenediimide and bdc = benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate) along with an isonicotinate based Co-MOF-2, [Co3(ina)4(OH)­(H2O)3]·H2O·NO3 (ina = isonicotinic acid). The Co-MOF-2 is similar to the previously reported isonicotinate based Co-MOF [Co3(ina)4(OH)­(C2H5OH)3]·NO3·C2H5OH·3H2O by Chen and co-workers. A single crystal analysis reveals that Co-MOFs 1 and 2 exhibit (5)-connected and (8)-connected 3D framework architecture having tts and hex topology, respectively. The gas sorption properties were also investigated for both Co-MOFs 1 and 2, and results are very promising for the host–guest chemistry. Besides this, Co-MOF-1 also shows promising solvatochromism behavior.

The Co-MOF-2 is similar to the previously reported isonicotinate based Co-MOF [Co3(ina)4(OH)(C2H5OH)3]⋅NO3⋅C2H5OH⋅3H2O by Chen and co-workers. A single crystal analysis reveals that Co-MOFs 1 and 2 exhibit (5)-connected and (8)-connected 3D framework architecture having tts and hex topology, respectively. The gas sorption properties were also investigated for both Co-MOFs 1 and 2, and results are very promising for the host-guest chemistry. Besides this, Co-MOF-1 also shows promising solvatochromism behavior.

elements.content: The starting materials 1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxylic dianhydride (NDA), 4-(aminomethyl)­pyridine, 1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid (bdc), and anhydrous DMF were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, LobaChemie, or TCI chemicals. Solvents 1, 2-dichlorobenzene (1,2-dcb) and metal salts Co­(NO3)2·6H2O and NaOH were purchased from the FINAR, AVRA, and CDH chemicals, respectively, and used as received. The microanalytical data were obtained with a FLASH EA 1112 Series CHNS Analyzer. The NMR spectroscopic measurements were carried out with a Bruker Avance 400 MHz spectrometer. The FTIR spectra were recorded with a Perkin–Elmer FTIR 2000 spectrometer. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurement were carried out on an SDT Q600 (V20.9 Build 20) instrument (Artisan Technology Group, Champaign, IL) under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C per min. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were recorded on a PANalytical X’PertPRO X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54059 Å). The samples were ground and subjected to the range of theta = 5–50° with a scan rate of 1° per minute at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The starting materials 1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxylic dianhydride (NDA), 4-(aminomethyl)pyridine, 1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid (bdc), and anhydrous DMF were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, LobaChemie, or TCI chemicals. Solvents 1, 2-dichlorobenzene (1,2-dcb) and metal salts Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and NaOH were purchased from the FINAR, AVRA, and CDH chemicals, respectively, and used as received. The microanalytical data were obtained with a FLASH EA 1112 Series CHNS Analyzer. The NMR spectroscopic measurements were carried out with a Bruker Avance 400 MHz spectrometer. The FTIR spectra were recorded with a Perkin-Elmer FTIR 2000 spectrometer. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurement were carried out on an SDT Q600 (V20.9 Build 20) instrument (Artisan Technology Group, Champaign, IL) under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C per min. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were recorded on a PANalytical X'PertPRO X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54059 Å). The samples were ground and subjected to the range of theta = 5-50° with a scan rate of 1° per minute at room temperature.

elements.content: The ligand dpmndi has been synthesized by using the literature protocol (Scheme S1) with slight modification. Here, a mixture of NDA (1 g, 3.73 mmol) and 4-(aminomethyl)­pyridine (0.807 g, 7.46 mmol) was stirred at 80–90 °C under N2 atmosphere in anhydrous DMF (20 mL) for 12 h, affording an orange-brown suspension. The solid was filtered off and washed with acetonitrile and acetone and finally dried under vacuum. Yield: 1.50 g (90% based on NDA). FT-IR (KBr disc, selected peaks, cm–1): 3076 (C–H), 2958 (CH2), 1702 (CO; imide), 1651 (−N–CO; imide), 1601, 1581, 1491 (for pyridyl group). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δ = 8.74 (s, 4H), 8.50 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 4H), 7.40 (d, J = 5.8 Hz, 4H), 5.31 (s, 4H). Anal. Calcd for C26H16N4O4: C, 69.64%; H, 3.60%; N, 12.49%. Found: C, 69.59%; H, 3.65%; N, 12.53%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Ligand N,N'-Bis(4-pyridylmethyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalenediimide (dpmndi)

The ligand dpmndi has been synthesized by using the literature protocol (Scheme S1) with slight modification. Here, a mixture of NDA (1 g, 3.73 mmol) and 4-(aminomethyl)pyridine (0.807 g, 7.46 mmol) was stirred at 80-90 °C under N2 atmosphere in anhydrous DMF (20 mL) for 12 h, affording an orange-brown suspension. The solid was filtered off and washed with acetonitrile and acetone and finally dried under vacuum. Yield: 1.50 g (90% based on NDA). FT-IR (KBr disc, selected peaks, cm-1): 3076 (C-H), 2958 (CH2), 1702 (CO; imide), 1651 (-N-CO; imide), 1601, 1581, 1491 (for pyridyl group). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δ = 8.74 (s, 4H), 8.50 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 4H), 7.40 (d, J = 5.8 Hz, 4H), 5.31 (s, 4H). Anal. Calcd for C26H16N4O4: C, 69.64%; H, 3.60%; N, 12.49%. Found: C, 69.59%; H, 3.65%; N, 12.53%.

elements.content: A mixture of ligands dpmndi (10 mg, 0.022 mmol) and H2bdc (7 mg, 0.044 mmol), Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (12 mg, 0.044 mmol), and solvents DMF/1,2-dichorobenzene (4:1, v/v, 2.5 mL) followed by the addition of few drops of 2 M NaOH were placed in 5 mL glass vial with screw caps and sonicated for 15 min, then placed in a programmable oven at 80 °C for 72 h, and finally cooled to room temperature. The needle-shaped dark green color crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray analysis were collected. Yield, 12.6 mg (58.6%; based on dpmndi). Anal. Calcd For C42H24Co2N4O12·DMF: C, 55.86%; H, 3.23%; N, 7.24%. Found: C, 55.76%; H, 3.26%; N, 7.15%. FT-IR spectrum (selected peaks): 1708 (CO), 1673, 1613 (COO) cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Co2(dpmndi)(bdc)2]⋅DMF (Co-MOF-1)

A mixture of ligands dpmndi (10 mg, 0.022 mmol) and H2bdc (7 mg, 0.044 mmol), Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (12 mg, 0.044 mmol), and solvents DMF/1,2-dichorobenzene (4:1, v/v, 2.5 mL) followed by the addition of few drops of 2 M NaOH were placed in 5 mL glass vial with screw caps and sonicated for 15 min, then placed in a programmable oven at 80 °C for 72 h, and finally cooled to room temperature. The needle-shaped dark green color crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray analysis were collected. Yield, 12.6 mg (58.6%; based on dpmndi). Anal. Calcd For C42H24Co2N4O12⋅DMF: C, 55.86%; H, 3.23%; N, 7.24%. Found: C, 55.76%; H, 3.26%; N, 7.15%. FT-IR spectrum (selected peaks): 1708 (CO), 1673, 1613 (COO) cm-1.

elements.content: The Co-MOF-2 was also synthesized using the solvothermal protocol. In a 5 mL glass vial with screw cap, a mixture of ligand dpmndi (10 mg, 0.022 mmol), Hina (5.4 mg, 0.044 mmol), and Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (12 mg, 0.044 mmol) in DMF (3 mL) was initially sonicated for 10–15 min and then placed in a programmable oven at 90 °C for 48 h, which was then slowly cooled to room temperature. The block-shaped light red color crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray analysis were isolated. Yield: 35 mg (52.79% based Hina). Anal. Calcd For C24H23Co3N4O12·H2O·NO3: C, 35.31%; H, 3.09%; N, 8.58%. Found: C, 36.21%; H, 2.95%; N, 8.81%. FT-IR spectrum (selected peaks): 3350 (OH), 1648, 1587 (COO) cm–1. The formulation of Co-MOF-2 is based on the elemental and TGA analyses along with the single crystal analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Co3(ina)4(OH)(H2O)3]⋅H2O⋅NO3 (Co-MOF-2)

The Co-MOF-2 was also synthesized using the solvothermal protocol. In a 5 mL glass vial with screw cap, a mixture of ligand dpmndi (10 mg, 0.022 mmol), Hina (5.4 mg, 0.044 mmol), and Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (12 mg, 0.044 mmol) in DMF (3 mL) was initially sonicated for 10-15 min and then placed in a programmable oven at 90 °C for 48 h, which was then slowly cooled to room temperature. The block-shaped light red color crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray analysis were isolated. Yield: 35 mg (52.79% based Hina). Anal. Calcd For C24H23Co3N4O12⋅H2O⋅NO3: C, 35.31%; H, 3.09%; N, 8.58%. Found: C, 36.21%; H, 2.95%; N, 8.81%. FT-IR spectrum (selected peaks): 3350 (OH), 1648, 1587 (COO) cm-1. The formulation of Co-MOF-2 is based on the elemental and TGA analyses along with the single crystal analysis.

elements.content: Suitable, apparently single crystals for Co-MOFs 1 and 2 were selected and data were collected on one of these single crystals at 298(2) K on a Rigaku Super Nova HyPix3000 diffractometer with monochromatic Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Diffraction data were processed by the CrysalisProv39.31, followed by absorption correction with the included Scale3 ABSPACK program. The structures were solved by intrinsic phasing with the SHELXS structure solution program and refinement were carried out with SHELXL, using the Olex2 GUI. The hydrogen atoms were fixed at the calculated positions with isotropic thermal parameters. In the crystal structures of Co-MOF-1, positional disorder was observed for the guest DMF molecule, and the contribution of DMF molecule is added in the empirical formula (see for detail). In case of Co-MOF-1, the solvent accessible void (SAVs) volume is calculated without removing lattice DMF molecule as obtained by using grid points/probe radius of 1.2 Å from the nearest van der Waals surface with the PLATON. Details of the crystallographic data collection and structural solution parameter and selected bond lengths are given in (see Table S1 for hydrogen bonding details).
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Diffraction Analysis

Suitable, apparently single crystals for Co-MOFs 1 and 2 were selected and data were collected on one of these single crystals at 298(2) K on a Rigaku Super Nova HyPix3000 diffractometer with monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Diffraction data were processed by the CrysalisProv39.31, followed by absorption correction with the included Scale3 ABSPACK program. The structures were solved by intrinsic phasing with the SHELXS structure solution program and refinement were carried out with SHELXL, using the Olex2 GUI. The hydrogen atoms were fixed at the calculated positions with isotropic thermal parameters. In the crystal structures of Co-MOF-1, positional disorder was observed for the guest DMF molecule, and the contribution of DMF molecule is added in the empirical formula (see  for detail). In case of Co-MOF-1, the solvent accessible void (SAVs) volume is calculated without removing lattice DMF molecule as obtained by using grid points/probe radius of 1.2 Å from the nearest van der Waals surface with the PLATON. Details of the crystallographic data collection and structural solution parameter and selected bond lengths are given in  (see Table S1 for hydrogen bonding details).

The N2, H2, CH4, and CO2 sorption experiments were carried out on an Autosorb-IQ2 gas adsorption analyzer (Quantachrome Instruments) at variable temperatures. The samples were activated prior to the measurements by soaking the crystals of Co-MOFs 1 and 2 in CH3OH for 3 days (fresh CH3OH replaced every 12 h), and then pumped under the dynamic vacuum at 60 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Sorption Measurements

The N2, H2, CH4, and CO2 sorption experiments were carried out on an Autosorb-IQ2 gas adsorption analyzer (Quantachrome Instruments) at variable temperatures. The samples were activated prior to the measurements by soaking the crystals of Co-MOFs 1 and 2 in CH3OH for 3 days (fresh CH3OH replaced every 12 h), and then pumped under the dynamic vacuum at 60 °C.

elements.content: The ligand dpmndi has been prepared using the literature protocol with slight modification, and details are provided with the . Whereas the solvothermal reaction of dpmndi with Co­(NO3)2·6H2O in the presence of H2bdc as coligand afforded [Co2(dpmndi)­(bdc)2)]·DMF (Co-MOF-1) (see ), the reaction of Co­(NO3)2·6H2O and isonicotinic acid gave [Co3(ina)4(OH)­(H2O)3]·H2O·NO3 (Co-MOF-2), which is very similar to {Co3(OH)}-based cluster reported by Chen and co-workers. The ligand dpmndi and Co-MOFs 1 and 2 are well characterized by various analytical and spectroscopic techniques (Figures S1–S3, Supporting Information). The FT-IR spectra of Co-MOFs 1 and 2 (Figure S3) show strong bands between 1605–1577 cm–1 due to the v COO stretches. In addition, broad features between 3400–3430 cm–1 were indicative of the presence of coordinated and lattice water molecules in Co-MOF-2. The microanalysis results and single crystal analysis also support this observation.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

The ligand dpmndi has been prepared using the literature protocol with slight modification, and details are provided with the . Whereas the solvothermal reaction of dpmndi with Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O in the presence of H2bdc as coligand afforded [Co2(dpmndi)(bdc)2)]⋅DMF (Co-MOF-1) (see ), the reaction of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and isonicotinic acid gave [Co3(ina)4(OH)(H2O)3]⋅H2O⋅NO3 (Co-MOF-2), which is very similar to {Co3(OH)}-based cluster reported by Chen and co-workers. The ligand dpmndi and Co-MOFs 1 and 2 are well characterized by various analytical and spectroscopic techniques (Figures S1-S3, Supporting Information). The FT-IR spectra of Co-MOFs 1 and 2 (Figure S3) show strong bands between 1605-1577 cm-1 due to the v COO stretches. In addition, broad features between 3400-3430 cm-1 were indicative of the presence of coordinated and lattice water molecules in Co-MOF-2. The microanalysis results and single crystal analysis also support this observation.

elements.content: A single crystal X-ray analysis of Co-MOF-1 reveals that it crystallizes in the tetragonal unit cell with the space group of I 4 /mcm. The asymmetric unit of Co-MOF-1 consists of a half dpmndi ligand, a half bdc2– ligand, and a half cobalt ion, as the mirror plane bisects them all, and a quarter of a lattice-occluded DMF molecule (disordered) as it lies on a 4-fold screw axis passing through it. The framework is neutral as positive charge contributed by half of cobalt ion is balanced by half of the bdc2– ligand in the asymmetric unit. As shown in a, the Co­(II) ion of Co-MOF-1 displayed distorted square pyramidal geometry, wherein the four equatorial sites are occupied by the four Ocarboxylate atoms coming from four different bdc2– ligands, while the apical site is occupied by Npyridyl atom stemming from dpmndi ligand. The coordination mode for bdc2– ligands is μ2(η1, η1) resulting in a binuclear paddle-wheel secondary building unit [Co2(COO)4(N)2] (d) with a Co–Co distance equal to 2.731(4) Å, which is in the close range of cobalt–cobalt binuclear clusters Co2(RCOO)4 complexes. The Co–O and Co–N bonds fall in the range 2.02–2.07 Å (Table S1). Since the two pyridyl arms can rotate freely about the methylene groups, both anti- and syn-conformations are possible for dpmndi.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Description of [Co2(dpmndi)(bdc)2]⋅DMF (Co-MOF-1)

A single crystal X-ray analysis of Co-MOF-1 reveals that it crystallizes in the tetragonal unit cell with the space group of I 4 /mcm. The asymmetric unit of Co-MOF-1 consists of a half dpmndi ligand, a half bdc2- ligand, and a half cobalt ion, as the mirror plane bisects them all, and a quarter of a lattice-occluded DMF molecule (disordered) as it lies on a 4-fold screw axis passing through it. The framework is neutral as positive charge contributed by half of cobalt ion is balanced by half of the bdc2- ligand in the asymmetric unit. As shown in a, the Co(II) ion of Co-MOF-1 displayed distorted square pyramidal geometry, wherein the four equatorial sites are occupied by the four Ocarboxylate atoms coming from four different bdc2- ligands, while the apical site is occupied by Npyridyl atom stemming from dpmndi ligand. The coordination mode for bdc2- ligands is μ2(η1, η1) resulting in a binuclear paddle-wheel secondary building unit [Co2(COO)4(N)2] (d) with a Co-Co distance equal to 2.731(4) Å, which is in the close range of cobalt-cobalt binuclear clusters Co2(RCOO)4 complexes. The Co-O and Co-N bonds fall in the range 2.02-2.07 Å (Table S1). Since the two pyridyl arms can rotate freely about the methylene groups, both anti- and syn-conformations are possible for dpmndi.

elements.content: (a) ORTEP depiction of the crystal structure of Co-MOF-1 (50% probability level). Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Color code: gray, C; cyan, N; red, O; Co, brown. (b) Construction of a binuclear Co-paddle-wheel by the linkage of the Co­(II) ion with dpmndi and bdc2–. (c) Packing view of the Co-MOF-1 along the a-axis displaying three different kinds of 1D channel. (d) Packing view of the Co-MOF-1 along c-axis showing cage-to-cage connection and porous nature of the structure. (e) Cage built from four [Co2(COO)4(N)2], two dpmndi, and two bdc2– ligands and exhibiting porous nature as shown by yellow and magenta balls. (g) Orthogonal interlocking of metallocyclic rings and π···π stacking between the NDI cores. (h) (5)-connected framework structure of Co-MOF-1 having tts topology and point symbol {33.43.54}.

(b) Construction of a binuclear Co-paddle-wheel by the linkage of the Co(II) ion with dpmndi and bdc2-. (c) Packing view of the Co-MOF-1 along the a-axis displaying three different kinds of 1D channel. (d) Packing view of the Co-MOF-1 along c-axis showing cage-to-cage connection and porous nature of the structure. (e) Cage built from four [Co2(COO)4(N)2], two dpmndi, and two bdc2- ligands and exhibiting porous nature as shown by yellow and magenta balls. (g) Orthogonal interlocking of metallocyclic rings and π⋅⋅⋅π stacking between the NDI cores. (h) (5)-connected framework structure of Co-MOF-1 having tts topology and point symbol {33.43.54}.

elements.content: In the crystal structure of Co-MOF-1, both 4-pyridyl arms are located on the same sides of the central NDI core in syn-conformation, thus generating a microsized metallacyclic cage with Co···Co distance of 13.096 and 17.090 Å (e) encapsulating the lattice DMF. Moreover, the microsized cage shows an internal cavity of 8.6 Å diameter (c).
elements.clean_text: In the crystal structure of Co-MOF-1, both 4-pyridyl arms are located on the same sides of the central NDI core in syn-conformation, thus generating a microsized metallacyclic cage with Co⋅⋅⋅Co distance of 13.096 and 17.090 Å (e) encapsulating the lattice DMF. Moreover, the microsized cage shows an internal cavity of 8.6 Å diameter (c).

elements.content: The two dpmndi ligands bridge two paddle-wheel secondary building units to form a metallacycle Co4(dpmndi)2, which further extends into a two-dimensional network through bdc2– ligands. Interestingly, these adjacent two-dimensional sheets further interlace via the π···π interactions between the NDI cores of each cage in parallel fashion resulting in a polycatenated 3D architecture as shown in g,h. The crystal packing reveals the formation of porous channels running along the crystallographic c-axis as shown in d,e and S4. The structure of Co-MOF-1 possesses two types of channels running along the crystallographic c-axis, having the dimensions of 15.46 × 15.46 Å2 and 15.91 × 16.87 Å2 (containing DMF molecule), respectively. Notably, the structure of Co-MOF-1 exhibits solvent accessible voids (SAVs) of 30.9% per unit cell volume (3273/10587 Å3) (Figure S4) as suggested by PLATON analysis without removal of guest molecules. Importantly, the topological analysis of Co-MOF-1 shows an interesting (5)-connected uninodal network with tts topology and point symbol of {33.43.54} (g). The detailed crystallographic information for Co-MOF-1 is given in .

elements.content: The solvothermal reaction of dpmndi, isonicotinic acid, and nitrate salt of cobalt afforded a 3D porous framework of Co-MOF-2 (as shown in ), which is very similar to the previously reported Co-MOF [Co3(ina)4(OH)­(C2H5OH)3]­[NO3]·C2H5OH·3H2O. The structure of Co-MOF-2 reveals that all the cobalt ions show octahedral geometry containing an aqua ligand coordinated to each of the cobalt ions in contrast to the alcoholic solvent as observed in previous report. The structure of Co-MOF-2 possesses triangle windows running along the crystallographic a-axis and having the dimensions of 9.04 × 9.08 × 9.14 Å. Notably, the structure of Co-MOF-2 contains the 45% SAVs per unit cell volume (2080/4625.47 Å3) as shown in Figure S5, which is more than doubled that of 19.8% reported for Co-MOF [Co3(ina)4(OH)­(C2H5OH)3]·NO3·C2H5OH·3H2O. The detail crystallographic information for Co-MOF-2 is given in .
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Description of [Co3(ina)4(OH)(H2O)3]⋅H2O⋅NO3 (Co-MOF-2)

The solvothermal reaction of dpmndi, isonicotinic acid, and nitrate salt of cobalt afforded a 3D porous framework of Co-MOF-2 (as shown in ), which is very similar to the previously reported Co-MOF [Co3(ina)4(OH)(C2H5OH)3][NO3]⋅C2H5OH⋅3H2O. The structure of Co-MOF-2 reveals that all the cobalt ions show octahedral geometry containing an aqua ligand coordinated to each of the cobalt ions in contrast to the alcoholic solvent as observed in previous report. The structure of Co-MOF-2 possesses triangle windows running along the crystallographic a-axis and having the dimensions of 9.04 × 9.08 × 9.14 Å. Notably, the structure of Co-MOF-2 contains the 45% SAVs per unit cell volume (2080/4625.47 Å3) as shown in Figure S5, which is more than doubled that of 19.8% reported for Co-MOF [Co3(ina)4(OH)(C2H5OH)3]⋅NO3⋅C2H5OH⋅3H2O. The detail crystallographic information for Co-MOF-2 is given in .

elements.content: As thermal stability of any compound is one of the important features for the functionality of a material, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) were employed for the Co-MOFs 1 and 2. TGA of Co-MOF-1 shows weight loss of 8.18% (observed), which fit closely with the calculated weight loss of 7.58% in the temperature range of 50 and 250 °C, corresponding to the liberation of one lattice-occluded DMF molecule (Figure S6). Co-MOF-2 exhibits its first weight loss of 18.18% (observed), which corresponds to the liberation of three coordinated water molecules, one hydroxide ion, one lattice-occluded water molecule, and one lattice nitrate anion (ca. 18.51%) in the temperature range of 50 to 200 °C (Figure S6). DSC analysis also supported the TGA findings for Co-MOFs 1 and 2, as it shows the respective weight loss in its first transition in the exothermic region (Figure S7). To analyze the phase purity of the bulk samples, powder X-ray diffraction measurement was been carried out for the both samples, and it noticed that the simulated diffraction pattern generated from the single crystal X-ray diffraction nicely fit with the as-synthesized one, thus advocating the purity of the bulk compounds ().
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analyses and PXRD

As thermal stability of any compound is one of the important features for the functionality of a material, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) were employed for the Co-MOFs 1 and 2. TGA of Co-MOF-1 shows weight loss of 8.18% (observed), which fit closely with the calculated weight loss of 7.58% in the temperature range of 50 and 250 °C, corresponding to the liberation of one lattice-occluded DMF molecule (Figure S6). Co-MOF-2 exhibits its first weight loss of 18.18% (observed), which corresponds to the liberation of three coordinated water molecules, one hydroxide ion, one lattice-occluded water molecule, and one lattice nitrate anion (ca. 18.51%) in the temperature range of 50 to 200 °C (Figure S6). DSC analysis also supported the TGA findings for Co-MOFs 1 and 2, as it shows the respective weight loss in its first transition in the exothermic region (Figure S7). To analyze the phase purity of the bulk samples, powder X-ray diffraction measurement was been carried out for the both samples, and it noticed that the simulated diffraction pattern generated from the single crystal X-ray diffraction nicely fit with the as-synthesized one, thus advocating the purity of the bulk compounds ().

elements.content: To probe the porous nature of the Co-MOFs 1 and 2, the adsorption–desorption isotherms for N2, H2, CH4, and CO2 were measured for the activated samples, and their respective isotherms are depicted in . The N2 and H2 gas sorption isotherms of Co-MOFs 1 and 2 were recorded at 77 K, whereas for CH4 its 295 K. For both Co-MOFs 1 and 2, the CO2 adsorption isotherms were recorded at 273 and 298 K, respectively. The N2 and H2 gas isotherms of Co-MOF-1 show uptakes of 126.87 and 62.15 cm3 g–1, respectively, whereas CH4 exhibits only the surface sorption (2.26 cm3 g–1). As shown in a, CO2 uptake capacities of Co-MOF-1 at 273 and 298 K are 76.48 and 33.03 cm3 g–1, respectively, which are better/comparable to several microporous materials reported in the literature (see Table S3 in the Supporting Information for a comprehensive list of MOFs and their sorption behavior). The N2 sorption exhibits an adsorption–desorption type-II isotherm. However, H2 and CO2 adsorption by Co-MOF-1 shows the reversible type-I isotherm. The high uptake of N2, H2, and CO2 compare to CH4 predominantly ascribed to their diverse electrostatic interactions with the surface of the porous channels/voids and their large quadrupole moment (CO2 = 4.30 × 10–26 esu–1 cm–1, N2 = 1.52 × 10–26 esu–1 cm–1, H2 = 0.66 × 10–26 esu–1 cm–1, and 0 esu–1 cm–1 for CH4). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area and pore volume of Co-MOF-1 was found to be 69.4 m2 g–1 and 0.09 cm3 g–1, respectively, which are estimated from the N2 sorption data.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption Studies

To probe the porous nature of the Co-MOFs 1 and 2, the adsorption-desorption isotherms for N2, H2, CH4, and CO2 were measured for the activated samples, and their respective isotherms are depicted in . The N2 and H2 gas sorption isotherms of Co-MOFs 1 and 2 were recorded at 77 K, whereas for CH4 its 295 K. For both Co-MOFs 1 and 2, the CO2 adsorption isotherms were recorded at 273 and 298 K, respectively. The N2 and H2 gas isotherms of Co-MOF-1 show uptakes of 126.87 and 62.15 cm3 g-1, respectively, whereas CH4 exhibits only the surface sorption (2.26 cm3 g-1). As shown in a, CO2 uptake capacities of Co-MOF-1 at 273 and 298 K are 76.48 and 33.03 cm3 g-1, respectively, which are better/comparable to several microporous materials reported in the literature (see Table S3 in the Supporting Information for a comprehensive list of MOFs and their sorption behavior). The N2 sorption exhibits an adsorption-desorption type-II isotherm. However, H2 and CO2 adsorption by Co-MOF-1 shows the reversible type-I isotherm. The high uptake of N2, H2, and CO2 compare to CH4 predominantly ascribed to their diverse electrostatic interactions with the surface of the porous channels/voids and their large quadrupole moment (CO2 = 4.30 × 10-26 esu-1 cm-1, N2 = 1.52 × 10-26 esu-1 cm-1, H2 = 0.66 × 10-26 esu-1 cm-1, and 0 esu-1 cm-1 for CH4). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area and pore volume of Co-MOF-1 was found to be 69.4 m2 g-1 and 0.09 cm3 g-1, respectively, which are estimated from the N2 sorption data.

elements.content: Under similar conditions, the N2 sorption isotherm of Co-MOF-2 shows 52.38 cm3 g–1 uptake capacity. However, H2 and CH4 isotherms exhibit low uptakes of 15.96 and 2.43 cm3 g–1, respectively. In addition, CO2 isotherms of Co-MOF-2 display uptakes of 37.91 and 31.28 cm3 g–1 at 273 and 298 K, respectively. The high uptake capacity shown by N2 and CO2 gases compare to H2 and CH4 possibly because of their greater affinity toward the micropores of Co-MOF-2. The BET surface area and pore volume of Co-MOF-2 was found to be 22.4 m2 g–1 and 0.048 cm3 g–1, respectively. Importantly, TGA profile of the activated sample of Co-MOFs 1 and 2 clearly indicates that their framework integrity remain intact even after the loss of guest solvent molecules (see Figure S9 of Supporting Information). In addition, activated XRD pattern and post-gas adsorption analysis sample of Co-MOFs 1 and 2 also advocated that both these materials keep intact their crystallinity and framework integrity (see ).

elements.content: Moreover, to probe the affinity of Co-MOF-1 for CO2, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) was calculated in accordance with the Clausius–Clapeyron equation by fitting sorption isotherms at 298 K. The Q st isotherm of Co-MOF-1 shows heat of adsorption of 32.41 kJ mol–1 (see c), which is higher than the enthalpy of liquefaction of CO2 (17 kJ mol–1) and comparable to Q st values of recently reported MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Moreover, to probe the affinity of Co-MOF-1 for CO2, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) was calculated in accordance with the Clausius-Clapeyron equation by fitting sorption isotherms at 298 K. The Q st isotherm of Co-MOF-1 shows heat of adsorption of 32.41 kJ mol-1 (see c), which is higher than the enthalpy of liquefaction of CO2 (17 kJ mol-1) and comparable to Q st values of recently reported MOFs.

elements.content: The Q st value (32.41 kJ mol–1) and SAVs (30.9%) for Co-MOF-1 are higher than those of several reported Co-MOFs. Co-MOF-2 also exhibits quite similar surface coverage with Q st value of 30.26 kJ mol–1. Notably, the Q st values for Co-MOF-1 at the low surface coverage region steadily decreases and increases at the high surface coverage region (see c). This result indicates that the preadsorbed CO2 molecules in the channels of Co-MOF-1 interact strongly with other incoming CO2 molecules resulting in a high Q st value. However, the Q st values for Co-MOF-2 initially increase upon the increase of CO2 uptake and decrease at higher coverage region (see c). These observations also clearly support the idea that the absorption of a particular gas not only depends on the BET surface area and pore volume of a porous material but also depends on other factors such as affinity of that particular gas toward the framework, open metal sites, arrangement of the pores, and so on.

elements.content: In the literature, reports are available wherein porous MOFs have been used for the inclusion of various analytes and their color change was explored; however, their numbers are rationally scarce. Still, this is a challenging task for the researcher working in the domain of MOFs and their applications to develop both the stable pores and solvatochromism in a single material. So, based on this aforementioned fact, we have also investigated the solvatochromic behavior of Co-MOFs 1 and 2 by immersing their crystals in a number of solvents such as CH3OH, CHCl3, CH2Cl2, diethyl ether, hexane, THF, CH3CN, DMF, DMA, and DMSO. Notably, we observed a color change from colorless to green (in DMA) and red (in DMSO) for Co-MOF-1 at room temperature. This color change might be due to the exchange of guest DMF molecule (molecular dimension, 5.84 × 6.74 Å2) by the DMA (molecular dimension, 6.31 × 7.25 Å2) or DMSO (molecular dimension, 5.99 × 6.26 Å2) molecules, which are very comparative to the guest DMF molecule in terms of their molecular dimension (see Table S4). The presence of channels with dimensions of 15.46 × 15.46 Å2 and 15.91 × 16.87 Å2 in Co-MOF-1 also facilitate the diffusion of these analytes into the pores and thus the exchange process. The tendency to form strong C–H···O and C–H···π interaction between the host and guest molecules might be another reason for this exchange. However, under similar circumstances, we did not observe any color change for Co-MOF-2 (see Figure S8). The lack of an electron-rich framework architecture might be the cause for the absence of solvatochromic behavior in Co-MOF-2. The photographs of these experiments are shown in Figure S8 of the Supporting Information. The solvatochromic effect was further analyzed by FT-IR, TGA, UV–vis, and XRD powder analysis (see Figures S9–S15). As expected, the impregnated sample of Co-MOF-1 in DMA (Co-MOF-1⊃DMA) exhibits νCO stretching band at 1671 cm–1 (Figure S10). However, under identical conditions, the impregnated sample of Co-MOF-1 in DMSO (Co-MOF-1⊃DMSO) shows a red shift of 20 cm–1, which clearly indicates that DMF in the channels of Co-MOF-1 is exchanged by DMSO (Figure S11), whereas a new broad peak appeared at 3423 cm–1 ascribed to the presence of water molecules along with DMSO in the cavity of Co-MOF-1. The TGA analysis of Co-MOF-1⊃DMA displays the first weight loss of 16.31% (observed 16.32%), which corresponds to the loss of two lattice-occluded DMA molecules in the region of 25–200 °C (see Figure S12). In a similar fashion, Co-MOF-1⊃DMSO exhibits an initial weight loss of 22.02% (observed 22.52%), which is nicely fitted with the loss of three DMSO and one water molecules in the region of 25–200 °C (see Figure S13), thereby strongly advocating the inclusion of DMA/DMSO molecules inside the channels of Co-MOF-1, resulting in visible color change. The UV–vis spectra and photographs of these inclusion compounds are shown in Figure S14. Due to the comparable polarity of the analysts {polarity index (P′): DMF, 6.4; DMA, 6.5, and DMSO, 7.2; DMSO is slightly higher than DMF and DMA}, we did not observe any significant shift in the UV–vis absorption bands after the solvent exchange. The XRD patterns of Co-MOF-1⊃DMA and Co-MOF-1⊃DMSO show that the crystallinity of Co-MOF-1 was retained even after the solvent exchange (Figure S15).
elements.clean_text:
Solvatochromism

In the literature, reports are available wherein porous MOFs have been used for the inclusion of various analytes and their color change was explored; however, their numbers are rationally scarce. Still, this is a challenging task for the researcher working in the domain of MOFs and their applications to develop both the stable pores and solvatochromism in a single material. So, based on this aforementioned fact, we have also investigated the solvatochromic behavior of Co-MOFs 1 and 2 by immersing their crystals in a number of solvents such as CH3OH, CHCl3, CH2Cl2, diethyl ether, hexane, THF, CH3CN, DMF, DMA, and DMSO. Notably, we observed a color change from colorless to green (in DMA) and red (in DMSO) for Co-MOF-1 at room temperature. This color change might be due to the exchange of guest DMF molecule (molecular dimension, 5.84 × 6.74 Å2) by the DMA (molecular dimension, 6.31 × 7.25 Å2) or DMSO (molecular dimension, 5.99 × 6.26 Å2) molecules, which are very comparative to the guest DMF molecule in terms of their molecular dimension (see Table S4). The presence of channels with dimensions of 15.46 × 15.46 Å2 and 15.91 × 16.87 Å2 in Co-MOF-1 also facilitate the diffusion of these analytes into the pores and thus the exchange process. The tendency to form strong C-H⋅⋅⋅O and C-H⋅⋅⋅π interaction between the host and guest molecules might be another reason for this exchange. However, under similar circumstances, we did not observe any color change for Co-MOF-2 (see Figure S8). The lack of an electron-rich framework architecture might be the cause for the absence of solvatochromic behavior in Co-MOF-2. The photographs of these experiments are shown in Figure S8 of the Supporting Information. The solvatochromic effect was further analyzed by FT-IR, TGA, UV-vis, and XRD powder analysis (see Figures S9-S15). As expected, the impregnated sample of Co-MOF-1 in DMA (Co-MOF-1⊃DMA) exhibits νCO stretching band at 1671 cm-1 (Figure S10). However, under identical conditions, the impregnated sample of Co-MOF-1 in DMSO (Co-MOF-1⊃DMSO) shows a red shift of 20 cm-1, which clearly indicates that DMF in the channels of Co-MOF-1 is exchanged by DMSO (Figure S11), whereas a new broad peak appeared at 3423 cm-1 ascribed to the presence of water molecules along with DMSO in the cavity of Co-MOF-1. The TGA analysis of Co-MOF-1⊃DMA displays the first weight loss of 16.31% (observed 16.32%), which corresponds to the loss of two lattice-occluded DMA molecules in the region of 25-200 °C (see Figure S12). In a similar fashion, Co-MOF-1⊃DMSO exhibits an initial weight loss of 22.02% (observed 22.52%), which is nicely fitted with the loss of three DMSO and one water molecules in the region of 25-200 °C (see Figure S13), thereby strongly advocating the inclusion of DMA/DMSO molecules inside the channels of Co-MOF-1, resulting in visible color change. The UV-vis spectra and photographs of these inclusion compounds are shown in Figure S14. Due to the comparable polarity of the analysts {polarity index (P'): DMF, 6.4; DMA, 6.5, and DMSO, 7.2; DMSO is slightly higher than DMF and DMA}, we did not observe any significant shift in the UV-vis absorption bands after the solvent exchange. The XRD patterns of Co-MOF-1⊃DMA and Co-MOF-1⊃DMSO show that the crystallinity of Co-MOF-1 was retained even after the solvent exchange (Figure S15).

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully demonstrated the synthesis and characterization of a unique Co-MOF-1; [Co2(dpmndi)­(bdc)2]·DMF along with an isonicotinate based Co-MOF-2; [Co3(ina)4(OH)­(H2O)3]·H2O·NO3. The structural analysis reveals that Co-MOFs 1 and 2 exhibit 3D porous framework architecture and display (4)-connected tts and (8)-connected hex topologies with point symbols {33.43.54} and {36.418.53.6}, respectively. Interestingly, Co-MOF-1 possesses two types of channels having dimensions of 15.46 × 15.46 Å2 and 15.91 × 16.87 Å2, whereas Co-MOF-2 contains a channel having the dimension of 9.04 × 9.08 × 9.14 Å. Notably, in both cases the channels are occupied by the occluded solvent molecules and thus open the door for host–guest chemistry in these molecules. In this perspective, gas sorption analysis was performed, and results show that Co-MOFs 1 and 2 show high uptake for N2 and CO2 compared to H2 and CH4. In addition, Co-MOFs 1 and 2 also display high isosteric heat of adsorption for CO2 gas. Notably, Co-MOF-1 also exhibits promising solvatochromism behavior.
elements.clean_text:
Summary and Conclusions

In summary, we have successfully demonstrated the synthesis and characterization of a unique Co-MOF-1; [Co2(dpmndi)(bdc)2]⋅DMF along with an isonicotinate based Co-MOF-2; [Co3(ina)4(OH)(H2O)3]⋅H2O⋅NO3. The structural analysis reveals that Co-MOFs 1 and 2 exhibit 3D porous framework architecture and display (4)-connected tts and (8)-connected hex topologies with point symbols {33.43.54} and {36.418.53.6}, respectively. Interestingly, Co-MOF-1 possesses two types of channels having dimensions of 15.46 × 15.46 Å2 and 15.91 × 16.87 Å2, whereas Co-MOF-2 contains a channel having the dimension of 9.04 × 9.08 × 9.14 Å. Notably, in both cases the channels are occupied by the occluded solvent molecules and thus open the door for host-guest chemistry in these molecules. In this perspective, gas sorption analysis was performed, and results show that Co-MOFs 1 and 2 show high uptake for N2 and CO2 compared to H2 and CH4. In addition, Co-MOFs 1 and 2 also display high isosteric heat of adsorption for CO2 gas. Notably, Co-MOF-1 also exhibits promising solvatochromism behavior.

cln_elements.content:
The ligand dpmndi has been synthesized by using the literature protocol (Scheme S1) with slight modification. Here, a mixture of NDA (1 g, 3.73 mmol) and 4-(aminomethyl)­pyridine (0.807 g, 7.46 mmol) was stirred at 80–90 °C under N2 atmosphere in anhydrous DMF (20 mL) for 12 h, affording an orange-brown suspension. The solid was filtered off and washed with acetonitrile and acetone and finally dried under vacuum. Yield: 1.50 g (90% based on NDA). FT-IR (KBr disc, selected peaks, cm–1): 3076 (C–H), 2958 (CH2), 1702 (CO; imide), 1651 (−N–CO; imide), 1601, 1581, 1491 (for pyridyl group). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δ = 8.74 (s, 4H), 8.50 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 4H), 7.40 (d, J = 5.8 Hz, 4H), 5.31 (s, 4H). Anal. Calcd for C26H16N4O4: C, 69.64%; H, 3.60%; N, 12.49%. Found: C, 69.59%; H, 3.65%; N, 12.53%.

Synthesis of [Co<sub>2</sub>(dpmndi)­(bdc)<sub>2</sub>]·DMF (Co-MOF-<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of ligands dpmndi (10 mg, 0.022 mmol) and H2bdc (7 mg, 0.044 mmol), Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (12 mg, 0.044 mmol), and solvents DMF/1,2-dichorobenzene (4:1, v/v, 2.5 mL) followed by the addition of few drops of 2 M NaOH were placed in 5 mL glass vial with screw caps and sonicated for 15 min, then placed in a programmable oven at 80 °C for 72 h, and finally cooled to room temperature. The needle-shaped dark green color crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray analysis were collected. Yield, 12.6 mg (58.6%; based on dpmndi). Anal. Calcd For C42H24Co2N4O12·DMF: C, 55.86%; H, 3.23%; N, 7.24%. Found: C, 55.76%; H, 3.26%; N, 7.15%. FT-IR spectrum (selected peaks): 1708 (CO), 1673, 1613 (COO) cm–1.

Synthesis of [Co<sub>3</sub>(ina)<sub>4</sub>(OH)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O·NO<sub>3</sub> (Co-MOF-<bold>2</bold>)

The Co-MOF-2 was also synthesized using the solvothermal protocol. In a 5 mL glass vial with screw cap, a mixture of ligand dpmndi (10 mg, 0.022 mmol), Hina (5.4 mg, 0.044 mmol), and Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (12 mg, 0.044 mmol) in DMF (3 mL) was initially sonicated for 10–15 min and then placed in a programmable oven at 90 °C for 48 h, which was then slowly cooled to room temperature. The block-shaped light red color crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray analysis were isolated. Yield: 35 mg (52.79% based Hina). Anal. Calcd For C24H23Co3N4O12·H2O·NO3: C, 35.31%; H, 3.09%; N, 8.58%. Found: C, 36.21%; H, 2.95%; N, 8.81%. FT-IR spectrum (selected peaks): 3350 (OH), 1648, 1587 (COO) cm–1. The formulation of Co-MOF-2 is based on the elemental and TGA analyses along with the single crystal analysis.

cln_elements.content:
The two dpmndi ligands bridge two paddle-wheel secondary building units to form a metallacycle Co4(dpmndi)2, which further extends into a two-dimensional network through bdc2– ligands. Interestingly, these adjacent two-dimensional sheets further interlace via the π···π interactions between the NDI cores of each cage in parallel fashion resulting in a polycatenated 3D architecture as shown in g,h. The crystal packing reveals the formation of porous channels running along the crystallographic c-axis as shown in d,e and S4. The structure of Co-MOF-1 possesses two types of channels running along the crystallographic c-axis, having the dimensions of 15.46 × 15.46 Å2 and 15.91 × 16.87 Å2 (containing DMF molecule), respectively. Notably, the structure of Co-MOF-1 exhibits solvent accessible voids (SAVs) of 30.9% per unit cell volume (3273/10587 Å3) (Figure S4) as suggested by PLATON analysis without removal of guest molecules. Importantly, the topological analysis of Co-MOF-1 shows an interesting (5)-connected uninodal network with tts topology and point symbol of {33.43.54} (g). The detailed crystallographic information for Co-MOF-1 is given in .

Crystal Structure Description of [Co<sub>3</sub>(ina)<sub>4</sub>(OH)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O·NO<sub>3</sub> (Co-MOF-<bold>2</bold>)

The solvothermal reaction of dpmndi, isonicotinic acid, and nitrate salt of cobalt afforded a 3D porous framework of Co-MOF-2 (as shown in ), which is very similar to the previously reported Co-MOF [Co3(ina)4(OH)­(C2H5OH)3]­[NO3]·C2H5OH·3H2O. The structure of Co-MOF-2 reveals that all the cobalt ions show octahedral geometry containing an aqua ligand coordinated to each of the cobalt ions in contrast to the alcoholic solvent as observed in previous report. The structure of Co-MOF-2 possesses triangle windows running along the crystallographic a-axis and having the dimensions of 9.04 × 9.08 × 9.14 Å. Notably, the structure of Co-MOF-2 contains the 45% SAVs per unit cell volume (2080/4625.47 Å3) as shown in Figure S5, which is more than doubled that of 19.8% reported for Co-MOF [Co3(ina)4(OH)­(C2H5OH)3]·NO3·C2H5OH·3H2O. The detail crystallographic information for Co-MOF-2 is given in .

Thermal Analyses and PXRD

As thermal stability of any compound is one of the important features for the functionality of a material, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) were employed for the Co-MOFs 1 and 2. TGA of Co-MOF-1 shows weight loss of 8.18% (observed), which fit closely with the calculated weight loss of 7.58% in the temperature range of 50 and 250 °C, corresponding to the liberation of one lattice-occluded DMF molecule (Figure S6). Co-MOF-2 exhibits its first weight loss of 18.18% (observed), which corresponds to the liberation of three coordinated water molecules, one hydroxide ion, one lattice-occluded water molecule, and one lattice nitrate anion (ca. 18.51%) in the temperature range of 50 to 200 °C (Figure S6). DSC analysis also supported the TGA findings for Co-MOFs 1 and 2, as it shows the respective weight loss in its first transition in the exothermic region (Figure S7). To analyze the phase purity of the bulk samples, powder X-ray diffraction measurement was been carried out for the both samples, and it noticed that the simulated diffraction pattern generated from the single crystal X-ray diffraction nicely fit with the as-synthesized one, thus advocating the purity of the bulk compounds ().

Gas Adsorption Studies

To probe the porous nature of the Co-MOFs 1 and 2, the adsorption–desorption isotherms for N2, H2, CH4, and CO2 were measured for the activated samples, and their respective isotherms are depicted in . The N2 and H2 gas sorption isotherms of Co-MOFs 1 and 2 were recorded at 77 K, whereas for CH4 its 295 K. For both Co-MOFs 1 and 2, the CO2 adsorption isotherms were recorded at 273 and 298 K, respectively. The N2 and H2 gas isotherms of Co-MOF-1 show uptakes of 126.87 and 62.15 cm3 g–1, respectively, whereas CH4 exhibits only the surface sorption (2.26 cm3 g–1). As shown in a, CO2 uptake capacities of Co-MOF-1 at 273 and 298 K are 76.48 and 33.03 cm3 g–1, respectively, which are better/comparable to several microporous materials reported in the literature (see Table S3 in the Supporting Information for a comprehensive list of MOFs and their sorption behavior). The N2 sorption exhibits an adsorption–desorption type-II isotherm. However, H2 and CO2 adsorption by Co-MOF-1 shows the reversible type-I isotherm. The high uptake of N2, H2, and CO2 compare to CH4 predominantly ascribed to their diverse electrostatic interactions with the surface of the porous channels/voids and their large quadrupole moment (CO2 = 4.30 × 10–26 esu–1 cm–1, N2 = 1.52 × 10–26 esu–1 cm–1, H2 = 0.66 × 10–26 esu–1 cm–1, and 0 esu–1 cm–1 for CH4). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area and pore volume of Co-MOF-1 was found to be 69.4 m2 g–1 and 0.09 cm3 g–1, respectively, which are estimated from the N2 sorption data.

Under similar conditions, the N2 sorption isotherm of Co-MOF-2 shows 52.38 cm3 g–1 uptake capacity. However, H2 and CH4 isotherms exhibit low uptakes of 15.96 and 2.43 cm3 g–1, respectively. In addition, CO2 isotherms of Co-MOF-2 display uptakes of 37.91 and 31.28 cm3 g–1 at 273 and 298 K, respectively. The high uptake capacity shown by N2 and CO2 gases compare to H2 and CH4 possibly because of their greater affinity toward the micropores of Co-MOF-2. The BET surface area and pore volume of Co-MOF-2 was found to be 22.4 m2 g–1 and 0.048 cm3 g–1, respectively. Importantly, TGA profile of the activated sample of Co-MOFs 1 and 2 clearly indicates that their framework integrity remain intact even after the loss of guest solvent molecules (see Figure S9 of Supporting Information). In addition, activated XRD pattern and post-gas adsorption analysis sample of Co-MOFs 1 and 2 also advocated that both these materials keep intact their crystallinity and framework integrity (see ).

Moreover, to probe the affinity of Co-MOF-1 for CO2, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) was calculated in accordance with the Clausius–Clapeyron equation by fitting sorption isotherms at 298 K. The Q st isotherm of Co-MOF-1 shows heat of adsorption of 32.41 kJ mol–1 (see c), which is higher than the enthalpy of liquefaction of CO2 (17 kJ mol–1) and comparable to Q st values of recently reported MOFs.

(a) ORTEP depiction of the crystal structure of Co-MOF-1 (50% probability level). Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Color code: gray, C; cyan, N; red, O; Co, brown. (b) Construction of a binuclear Co-paddle-wheel by the linkage of the Co­(II) ion with dpmndi and bdc2–. (c) Packing view of the Co-MOF-1 along the a-axis displaying three different kinds of 1D channel. (d) Packing view of the Co-MOF-1 along c-axis showing cage-to-cage connection and porous nature of the structure. (e) Cage built from four [Co2(COO)4(N)2], two dpmndi, and two bdc2– ligands and exhibiting porous nature as shown by yellow and magenta balls. (g) Orthogonal interlocking of metallocyclic rings and π···π stacking between the NDI cores. (h) (5)-connected framework structure of Co-MOF-1 having tts topology and point symbol {33.43.54}.

cln_elements.content: (a) ORTEP depiction of the crystal structure of Co-MOF-2 (50% probability level). Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (c) Packing view of the Co-MOF-2 along the a-axis displaying 1D channel. (d) Hexagonal packing view of the Co-MOF-2 along c-axis showing pores and channels. (e) Space-fill model of 3D porous framework of Co-MOF-2, wherein the coordinated water molecules penetrate toward the channels. (h) (8)-connected 3D framework architecture having hex topology with point symbol {36.418.53.6}.
